substitution.copyText: Guil. Good my Lord vochsafe me a word with you.
substitution.amendedText: Guil. Good my Lord, vouchsafe me a word with you.

substitution.copyText: Ham. I Sir, what of him?
substitution.amendedText: Ham. I, Sir, what of him?

substitution.copyText: Guil. Is in his retirement marvelous distempered.
substitution.amendedText: Guil. Is, in his retirement, marvelous distempered.--

substitution.copyText: Guil. No my Lord, with choler.
substitution.amendedText: Guil. No, my Lord, with choler.

substitution.copyText: Ham. Your wisdom should shew it self richer to signifie this to the Doctor: for for me to put him to his purgation, would perhaps plunge him into more choler.
substitution.amendedText: Ham. Your wisdom should shew it self more rich to signifie this to this Doctor: for, for me to put him to his purgation, would, perhaps, plunge him into more choler.

substitution.copyText: Ham. I am tame Sir, pronounce.
Guil. The Queen your mother in most great affliction of spirit hath sent me to you.
substitution.amendedText: Guil. The Queen your mother, in most great afflication of spirit, hath sent me to you.

substitution.copyText: Guild. Nay good my Lord this courtesie is not of the right breed
substitution.amendedText: Guild. Nay, good my Lord, this courtesie is not of the right breed

substitution.copyText: Ham. Make you a wholsome answer, my wit's diseas'd, but Sir, such answer as I can make you shall command, or rather as you say, my mother, therefore no more, but to the matter, my mother you say.
substitution.amendedText: Ham. Make you a wholsome answer: my wit's diseas'd. but, Sir, such answer as I can make you shall command; or, rather, as you say, my mother--

substitution.copyText: Ros. My Lord you once did love me.
substitution.amendedText: Ros. My Lord, you once did love me.

substitution.copyText: Ham. And do still by these pickers and stealers.
substitution.amendedText: Ham. So I do still, by these pickers and stealers.

substitution.copyText: Ham. I Sir, but while the grass grows; the Proverb is something
substitution.amendedText: Ham. I Sir, but while the grass grows-the Proverb is something
